verse: The Lord said to Moses,
“Speak to the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] and say to them, ‘When you enter the land that I am giving you as a home,

give the Lord offerings made by fire. These may be from your herds or flocks, as a smell pleasing to the Lord. These may be burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] or sacrifices for ·special promises [a vow], or as gifts to him, or as festival offerings.

The one who brings the offering shall also give the Lord a ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 2:1]. It should be ·two quarts [one-tenth of an ephah] of ·fine [choice] flour mixed with ·one quart [one-fourth of a hin] of olive oil.
Each time you offer a lamb as a burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] or sacrifice, also prepare ·one quart [one-fourth of a hin] of wine as a drink offering.

“‘If you are giving a ·male sheep [ram], also prepare a ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 2:1] of ·four quarts [two-tenths of an ephah] of ·fine [choice] flour mixed with ·one and one-fourth quarts [one-third of a hin] of olive oil.
Also prepare ·one and one-fourth quarts [one-third of a hin] of wine as a drink offering. Its smell will be pleasing to the Lord.
“‘If you prepare a young bull as a burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] or sacrifice, whether it is for a ·special promise [vow] or a ·fellowship [or peace; well-being] offering [Lev. 3:1] to the Lord,
bring a ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 2:1] with the bull. It should be ·six quarts [three-tenths of an ephah] of ·fine [choice] flour mixed with ·two quarts [half a hin] of olive oil.
Also bring ·two quarts [half a hin] of wine as a drink offering. This offering is made by fire, and its smell will be pleasing to the Lord.
Prepare each bull or ·male sheep [ram], lamb or young goat this way.
Do this for every one of the animals you bring.
“‘All ·citizens [natives] must do these things in this way, and the smell of their offerings by fire will be pleasing to the Lord.

·From now on [Throughout your generations] if ·foreigners [resident aliens] who live among you want to make offerings by fire so the smell will be pleasing to the Lord, they must offer them the same way you do.

As for the ·people [community; congregation; assembly], the ·law [statute; ordinance; requirement] is the same for you and for ·foreigners [resident aliens], and it will be ·from now on [a perpetual requirement]; you and the ·foreigners [resident aliens] are alike before the Lord.
The ·teachings [instructions; laws] and ·rules [regulations] are the same for you and for the ·foreigners [resident aliens] among you.’”
The Lord said to Moses,
“Tell the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel]: ‘You are going to another land, where I am taking you.
When you eat the food there, ·offer [elevate] part of it to the Lord.
·Offer [Elevate] a loaf of bread from the first of your ·grain [or dough], which will be your ·offering [elevation offering] from the threshing floor.
·From now on [Throughout your generations] ·offer [elevate] to the Lord the first part of your ·grain [or dough].
“‘Now what if you ·forget [unintentionally fail] to ·obey [do] any of these commands the Lord gave Moses?
These are the Lord’s commands given to you through Moses, which began the day the Lord ·gave them to [commanded] you and will continue ·from now on [throughout your generations].

If the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] ·forget [unintentionally fail] to ·obey [do] one of these commands, all the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] must offer a young bull as a burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17], a smell pleasing to the Lord. By law you must also give the ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 2:1] and the drink offering with it, and you must bring a male goat as a ·sin [or purification; Lev. 4:3] offering.

“‘The priest will ·remove that sin for all the Israelites so they will belong to the Lord [atone for all the community/congregation/assembly of the sons/children of Israel]. They are forgiven, because they ·didn’t know they were sinning [sinned unintentionally]. For the unintentional wrong they did they brought offerings to the Lord, an offering by fire and a ·sin [or purification; Lev. 4:3] offering.

So all of the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] of ·Israel [the sons/children of Israel] and the ·foreigners [resident aliens] living among them will be forgiven. ·No one meant to do wrong [They were all involved in unintentional sin].
“‘If just one person sins ·without meaning to [unintentionally], a year-old female goat must be brought for a ·sin [or purification; Lev. 4:3] offering.
The priest will ·remove [atone for] the sin of the person who sinned ·accidentally [unintentionally]. He will ·remove it before the Lord [atone for him]; and the person will be forgiven.
The same ·teaching [instruction; law] is for everyone who sins ·accidentally [unintentionally]—for those ·born Israelites [natives] and for ·foreigners [resident aliens] living among you.

“‘But anyone who sins ·on purpose [with a high hand; knowingly] ·is against [insults] the Lord and must be cut off from the people, whether it is ·someone born among you [a native] or a ·foreigner [resident alien].
That person has ·turned against [despised] the Lord’s word and has ·not obeyed [broken] his commands. Such a person must surely be cut off from the others. He is guilty.’”

header: A Man Worked on the Sabbath

verse: When the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] were still in the ·desert [wilderness], they found a man gathering wood on the Sabbath day [Gen. 2:2–3; Ex. 20:8–11; 35:2; Deut. 5:13–15].
Those who found him gathering wood brought him to Moses and Aaron and all the people.
They held the man under guard, because they did not know what to do with him.
Then the Lord said to Moses, “The man must surely die. All the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] must kill him by ·throwing stones at [stoning] him outside the camp.”
So all the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] took him outside the camp and stoned him to death, as the Lord commanded Moses.
The Lord said to Moses,

“Speak to the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] and tell them this: ‘·Tie several pieces of thread together and attach them to [Make fringes/tassels on] the corners of your clothes. Put a blue thread ·in each one of these tassels [on the fringe/tassel of each corner]. Wear them ·from now on [throughout your generations].

You will have these ·tassels [fringes] to look at to remind you of all the Lord’s commands. Then you will obey them and not ·be disloyal by following what your bodies and eyes want [follow after your own heart or your own eyes to be unfaithful/play the harlot after them].
Then you will remember to obey all my commands, and you will be God’s holy people.
I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of Egypt to be your God [Ex. 12–15]. I am the Lord your God.’”
